Re: License #: CB501003033
Dear Keia C Farr:
Attached is the Original Licensing Study Report for the above referenced facility. The
study has determined substantial compliance with applicable licensing statutes and
administrative rules. Therefore, an original license is issued.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Mark Hunter, Licensing Consultant
enclosure

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of independent living services. All files will be stored securely and there is
a cross shredder for CHRI. The office space is a designated area of the
applicant’s residential home. The home is located in a modern subdivision. The
home is relatively new, well maintained, and the designated office space is more
than adequate to meet the needs of providing administrative functions for
independent living services.
3

B. Program Description
As a nonprofit IRS 501(c)3 corporation serving youth 12-18, GYS operates to
effect change through multiple approaches, including but not limited to:
mentorship, empowerment, mental health and wellness, life skills, and pro-social
activities. Genesis Youth Services, Incorporated’s Independent Living Plus (ILP)
Program helps youth transition from residential or foster care to self-sufficiency in
the community through limited interventions. The Independent Living Plus (ILP)
Program helps 16–18-year-olds who are not yet ready for General Independent
Living (IL) by providing them with staff-supported housing and other services. The
Department of Health and Human Services, Probate Court, Circuit Court, and
other partnering programs make the majority of referrals to ILP. Youth receive
financial help from state/county funds granted by DHHS/CMO contract. It is
required that all youth will be either in school or employed. Youth must
demonstrate a capacity for and willingness to learn independent living skills in a
supported, structured ILP Program before transitioning into another living
arrangement. ILP serves to meet the youth’s specific independent living needs
and goals until he/she can step down to IL. The duration of the ILP Program will
vary as determined by the youth’s assessment of needs and strengths. The ILP
placement will not last longer than twelve months of initial intake without an
approved exception request from the referral source, (i.e. DHHS/CMO), and
cannot extend past the youth’s twentieth birthday
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
They agency is found in compliance with licensing rules.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on substantial compliance with the rules, it is recommended that a six-month
original license be issued.
________________________________May 15, 2025
Mark Hunter Date
